>>28189847
Saying "some time" eliminates mood as a problem. He may not be in the mood for a drink now, but he will be at some point.

Which of these I would recommend depends on whether you think you *might* like the guy and would like to spend a little time chatting to make your mind up, or whether you *know* you like him and want a full-on date; and also on whether you think he has had the time to make the same decision about you.

If I'm talking to someone on a dating app, for example, I would always try "Do you want to go for a drink or something?" because what's being proposed there is a short (maybe half-hour) meeting to determine whether the two of us would like to go on an actual date or not - not something you can decide when you haven't actually met face to face.

Similarly, if you've only just met the guy and he probably hasn't had time to decide if he likes you or not, steer things towards a casual hang-out with a possible date to follow if you both want to; if you already know each other quite well, then suggest an actual date up front.

I'm an early-career professional screenwriter (couple of credits, nothing significant). I'm based in Perth. I grew up in Australia, but I have an American citizenship through parents. Everyone's told me to go to LA because Australia's fucking tiny and jobs are few and far between.

I've been in an 8 year relationship with my high school girlfriend; in the 8 years that we've been together we've never had any massive arguments, we've never broken up and we've never cheated on each other - as far as I can tell. We share the same interests, humour and friendship circle. It's cliche but, she's not only my girlfriend, but she's also my best friend.

She doesn't want to go to LA and I wouldn't want her to sacrifice her dreams in order to facilitate my pipe dream. And ultimately, that's what it is, a pipe dream. Working as a professional writer is a bullshit, silly job where there's no money (unless you "make it") and no job security. I completely understand that the liklihood of me finding average writing work (which has shit pay) in LA is tiny, the liklihood of me "making it" is even smaller. So, I'm throwing away my savings, my social support network and the person who I've fallen in love with in order to chase a dream I'm statistically unlikely to succeed in.

I know that if I don't go to LA and try to "make it", I'll regret it for the rest of my life, and I'll end up as another Uni lecturer showing a shitty short film they made 40 years ago. I know that I'm throwing it all away, and I know that it's a necessary sacrifice.

Everything's stagnated, I can't concentrate on writing, I don't want to talk to anyone, I don't want to do anything. I've got to find a way to lift this mental weight and concentrate on what I'm supposed to be doing - which is writing.

I don't know why I'm writing this on a mongolian basket weaving forum, I just wanted to put it out there even if it's gross and cringe. I don't know who you are but thank you for reading this far, I love you :)

Australia isn't at all tiny, there are 2800 new Australian production companies every year. Screen Australia have lots of opportunities. So do VicScreen and Screen Queensland. Much of Hollywood are coming to Australia now to make movies because our industry is like Hollywood in the 70s.

If you want to try LA, have you considered moving there on a temporary basis. Say 6 or 12 months. You make your relationship temporary long distance for the duration of this experiment.

If you take off, you guys can have a conversation about what you want to do. A writer, writes, but that doesn't have to be in Hollywood once you've got your foot in the door.

If you don't take off in the set time period, you come back to Australia, you guys pick up where you left off and you look for work in Australia.

Just a thought that might be worth considering out loud with your mrs.

OP here's what worked for me after college. I had friends from school and stuff, but ended up making an entirely new secondary group of friends. I did this by going to concerts in town.

Just go to concerts. Don't have to be big concerts, just stuff at bars and smaller venues. Talk to people. Also buy cigarettes and smoke them, even if that's only when you're at a show. Smoking cigs is the absolute easiest way to meet new people. You can pretend you don't have a lighter, or some other people will ask you for a smoke and you can strike up a conversation. Obviously having some beers and drinking helps loosen things up too.

If you end up making really good friends, maybe you can travel to a concert or music festival in another city with them. Partying and taking psychedelic drugs with people over the course of a weekend is a great way to bond and establish long lasting friendships.

Personally I recommend the jam band or bluegrass scenes, but EDM is okay too I guess if you actually like that kind of music. Unfortunately most other genres will have more boring people that aren't into doing drugs or whatever and as a consequence they're often more reserved and harder to make friends with.

Ideally you'll make some friends from going to local shows, and then you'll end up going to house parties/after parties at their place. Just show up and be friendly, talk to people. No shame in your situation, just be like "yeah I moved here and work remotely, trying to have fun and meet people etc"

>I have no idea how to stay in touch inbetween dates? Texting her every day? Screams needy and intrusive.

Texting your GF everyday is normal, it's just how often you do it during the day that can make you look needy and weird. Once to twice a day is fine. You could also call or facetime her some time during the week.

>How do I into sex?

If she's similar to you then she is most likely as lost as you are when it comes to sex. Just see if things happen naturally when she comes over. Just don't pressure her about it since she's a virgin so give her a bit of time. If you guys date for awhile and no sex has happened it's not a bad idea for you to bring it up and see what she has to say about it.

>How do I combat the jealousy whenever she is not with me and I have no idea what she does?

The jealousy goes away over time and when you feel secure in the relationship. Just don't go crazy over it. She should also be open and transparent in what she's doing and let you know. My gf always tells me what she's doing and where she's at. You need to have a certain amount of trust in her for the relationship to work so take her word unless she proves she's not trustworthy.

>How do I prevent her noticing Gigachad at uni?
There's nothing you can really do except be a good BF. In any new relationship you're taking a leap of faith because you don't really know the person you're dating that well yet nor do you know what they're capable of doing. Although you have to keep in mind that it's also her first relationship and she's really young and inexperienced. Some relationships are just for experience and learning what you like and don't like. Not to say you have to worry she's going to leave you at any moment but you have to be aware it's possible she realizes you're not her type/compatible with her and then finds someone new.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28189760
>how you met
There wasn't much special about our meeting, I messaged her on a dating site. The important thing was me finally developing a mindset where I was ready for a relationship. That alone got me from zero female attention to getting dates consistently. And it keeps getting better - I'm noticing more and more women checking me out or smiling at me when I walk outside, even though my height is average, I'm a skelly, and put barely any effort into clothes/appearance. Romantic/sexual success is purely in your head to a staggering degree. Which btw goes directly against what you say in >>28189749
>what made her different from the women you've encountered until 30
Most importantly, she's a person of principles and integrity, which is (sadly) very rare. That allows me to trust and respect her, which as I said above is critically important. If you don't have this, you don't have a relationship.
We also have compatible values and lifestyles (very important) and share some intellectual interests and hobbies (less important than you might think).
>how everything worked out, despite your inexperience?
It's definitely been a bumpy ride, mainly because of my issues, but so far we're still together and things are looking good.
One important lesson is that keeping a relationship is a lot harder than getting one. Many foreveralones (including me, back then) think along the lines of "if only I met the right girl and made her see how great I am inside, things would just magically work". That's bullshit. Meeting the girl is the easy part.

I want to be loved and everything I'm doing is fundamentally for the sake of achieving that. But that's a fucking cope.

For one, I can't actually ever control the actions or emotions of other people, so the effort is wasted anyways. I can increase the likelihood of being loved, yes, but I can't force it, and I already experienced that I can't stop it from going away either.

And secondly, the kind of love I want is romantic love. But being desperate for love will just turn off the women I want to attract. Ideally, I would want to see a relationship as an accessoire to my life and not the purpose - but that's not how my mind works. I want a partner. Someone to go through the fire with me in mutual devotion.

I don't think I can ever find the love I want if I am myself. So I'll just have to pretend to be a stoic, strong man so that I can find someone to fall in love with the mask until I either crumble or one of us dies. At that point, I'm not even sure if its worth it, but the brief moments that I felt loved were one of the few times in my life that I had been happy after childhood.

Be mindful that people talk about things they don't really care about all the time to connect with others. Sometimes it's big things, like dreams. Sometimes it's small things, like music. Sometimes it's totally irrelevant things, like the weather. The important thing is if you enjoy talking to the person, not the subject at hand.

>I am being abused in a way

Make sure you are not coming after him aggressively for answers and whatever you do, do not overly react and cause an argument if he expresses something that seems unfair or hurtful. Literally just try to talk it out and get as much information from him as you can without shit escalating. Remember, you are just trying to gather answers and get his side of the story. Then sleep on it and reconsider your options. Are the things he said fair or not? Can you empathise with him? Did you get your points across and did he seem to listen or did he react badly? It's not going to be fun, but from your brief description the relationship is already unfun, so you have nothing to lose, but some potential happiness if things go well. Good luck.

Anon is right you probably have low testosterone. See your doctor and discuss with them, ask for a blood panel.

As for how to mentally grapple with those feelings, try to understand that your perception of gender has strayed from reality. Just because you don't engage with traditional "masculine" interests doesn't mean you are a woman, or aren't a man. Your primary feelings are likely a result of hormonal imbalances, and your secondary feelings are post-hoc rationalizations based on cognitive biases surrounding your perception of gender. You can't really do anything about the former without medical intervention or long-term lifestyle changes, but the latter is all in your head, so to speak. It's a matter of perception. You can think your way out of it, by recognizing and reconciling your biased worldview with a more objective interpretation. You don't need to like sports or cars or jack off 20 times a day to be male. Just because you don't look like Male Health magazine cover models doesn't mean you're a woman or something else. Masculinity or femininity are only facets of identity. You're an individual being before you are a male or female or scrimblo bimblo. Don't focus so much about which of those aspects you align with most because they shouldn't solely define you.

You have to look at any job application from the employers perspective. What is it that YOU can bring to THEM? How does hiring YOU benefit THEM? And here's the clincher, how does the benefits YOU bring stack up against or compete with ALL THE OTHER CANDIDATES?

Btw, "they get an employee" is not an answer to that question. So you need to start at the absolute bottom in a shithole dead end job where they need employee scale but face high turnover so basically everyone who applies gets hired. That's where you need to focus your applications. Build up some work experience over 18 months and you'll be in a much better position to get employed somewhere else.

Remember, a paper qualification is meaningless in 2023 without experience.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28101153
A job change isn't going to fix your life. You need an entire lifestyle change. I'm 26 and went through something similar around 24. I'm going to recommend something cliche, but it fucking works for reasons I will elaborate on. Get in shape. If you are fat lose weight. If you are skinny hit the gym. Yes it's a physical thing but we are mostly after the mental benefits. When you improve physically it does several things mentally (arguably it has more mental benefits than physical). First is you learn to be disciplined. This obviously effects every aspect of life. You need discipline to escape NEETdom. Next it will give you a taste of that "better life". You will see hard effort turn into tangible rewards that you can be proud of. This can set off a chain reaction into other aspects of life you feel are lacking. Next is confidence. You will be more confident in your self and your abilities and it could be enough of a boost to get you to pounce on opportunities you otherwise would have missed by being passive. Perhaps most important of all it will get you out of the house and give you a hobby that isn't doing anything for you. This can lead to meeting new people and gives you a common interest hobby that you can share and engage with most people over. Don't forget other people will treat you better too.

All of that doesn't even take into account the physical aspects that also play a role in mental health. You would likely see an increase in certain hormones such as testosterone and a decrease in things like estrogen. These hormones play a huge role in mental health and having screwed up hormones probably play a huge role in depression and the like. In my opinion physical improvement is the number one best thing you can do if you are unhappy with your life because it lays the foundation for everything else. This is coming from someone who was fat basically my entire life and was well on my way to being an eternal neet. Getting /fit/ is what saved me.

>>28176244
I can't read it. My specific situation will not really relate to you.

The TL;DR is that I am an /out/ist through and through and nothing is going to change that.

I was in the army before college. Biology degree. Wildly depressed, and medicated for it. In college I did an internship with a conservation agency and it was fun, but I did the "right thing" and after school I just kept pursuing my "career path." Nothing glamorous or financially enticing, mind you. At 27 I had a paradigm shift, some major life changes (sister offed herself and ended a toxic 6 year relationship) and I took some seasonal /out/ work in Alaska to try and clear my heart and my head. Quit taking Zoloft during this time.

Following this, I left and did a "normal" job for about 1.25 years before I again felt the urge to get the fuck back outside. I worked for an environmental compliance contractor. I had a moment of clarity when a guy who had been there for 12 years told me he had a zoology degree. It made me sad to know he once shared my dreams. So I had to leave. Almost every person I knew told me that, at ~28 it was too late for a "career change" and I should just stay in place and effectively work at the same place until I died. I've since worked for a few different agencies/places for the feds doing /out/ things. I do not make much money. My job security is tenuous. But I feel at peace and wouldn't change it.

The point of my story is simply that if you recognize something you are truly passionate about, you should just stick with it, because trying to convince yourself you are happier in some other capacity just results in you being miserable. I wouldn't do something just to feel like you're moving forward, if that makes sense. I wouldn't do something you aren't "super passionate" about. Do not go be a cop simply because it is SOMETHING. Its your life, anon. 1/4 of it is over. Do you want to waste another 1/2 doing something you don't even give a shit about?

Seems to be either give up and work at Walmart or FoLoW yOuR pAsSiOn DrEaMs ReAlLy Do CoMe TrUe!!!!! Both approaches are idiotic and will waste more of your time. To put it as bluntly and simply as possible, passion projects are for trust fund kids, those who have already made it, and regular people who have exceptional talent and drive. The general rule is that if you were in the latter group, you would know by 25 ie you would already have been grinding for years at that point and you'd start to see success. Sorry to say, that's not you, so on to step two.

Step two is employment, which mostly sucks. Some people will tell you about how they have a passion for making other people rich, but they're mostly just coping. The purpose of employment is to GET CASH FLOW so you can either exit employment or at least have the funds to cope with it and stay sane. You should find something you're good at that you can tolerate without burning out that MAXIMIZES cash flow and pursue that. Ideally it should pay you to learn skills that you can deploy outside of employment so you can exit employment sooner rather than later. Think of employment as a bridge from virgin neetdom to chad neetdom. Some examples of viable options are trades, sales, it, coding meme, internet marketing. You can get an entry-level job in most of these fields with little-to-no experience. Grind certs, lie, just do whatever you need to do. Then start accruing skills that you can use for freelancing, consulting, contracting, ect in order to exit employment. If you really want to you can do your art fag stuff on the side, and if that blows up and you stop showing up to your job, more power to you.

posts.sub: Should I rent an apartment?
posts.com:
Almost posted to /biz/ but I figured I want real advice instead of people just calling me poor. So, long story short I was working in another town then got a transfer to my hometown and I moved in with my parents instead of rushing to find an apartment. I've been here about 4 months now and I'm ready for my own place again, but I don't know if it's the smart move.

I got a promotion at work, and now I'm working from home and make $21/hr. This is definitely the best job I've ever had, I don't work that much, but the working from home part almost makes living with my parents that much more difficult. For what it's worth I am 31 years old.

The main reason I haven't gotten an apartment yet is I just want to save money. When I was living in the other city, I was paying $775 a month in rent, $70 for internet, and about $70 for internet, which were my only housing bills. So I was paying about 915 give or take per month in rent. My raise wasn't much, so outside of overtime I make about the same. I take home about 1350 a paycheck, or 2700 a month. The idea of spending nearly 1000 in living expense upsets me because then I only have 1700 bucks, and after groceries, booze, etc I could barely save 1000 a month. Most months living on my own I couldn't save more than maybe 400 or 500 tops. And I'm trying to invest in crypto and stocks too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28187540
Initially I was planning to stay with my parents for a year before moving out. This would allow me to save lots of money (living with them I spent 200ish per month total, and most of that is just booze and weed). However, I met a girl from tinder recently and sort of hit it off, ended up making out a lot and we hooked up in my car (no sex, just fooling around). She's a lot younger than me and also living with family, and I just felt cringe that we had to hook up in my car. She suggested we could get a hotel sometimes, and I'm not opposed, but then what I'm getting a hotel a few nights a month to bang? At that point I might as well just get an apartment

I'm just trying to decide what to do. I'm an only child and fairly lucky. My parents have even said that when I want to buy a house they'll help me with a down payment (not really sure how much, and I worry that even with a sizeable down payment from them that my income would still be too low for a bank to grant me a mortgage). And so I'm wondering should I just live at home for a year, try to save up 20 or 30k (barely doable) and then combine that with whatever they'd give for a down payment? Fwiw I'm not sure about my new job or if it will last long, and I don't want to buy a house and then get fired in a year or two and be fucked.

I'm just wondering based on my income what kind of apartment I can afford. Fwiw I am thinking of signing up for UberEats or something to make a few hundred extra a month, but not sure if that'll work.

I've been looking at apartments online, and rent prices seem to be coming down a bit, there's a few decent ones in some nice trendy areas that are between 750 and 900 a month. Really, I don't want to pay a dime more than 800 a month, but for the perfect place I'd prob go to 850 or 900.

Talking used to be overwhelming, jobs used to be overwhelming, school, all of it. Being a neet was really the only thing I could do well but it depressed the hell out of me.
A year ago I clicked and now I enjoy socializing and relationships, to the point where talking is easy and I never feel like I have to put up a mask. Jobs aren't overwhelming, I enjoy basically everything, etc. etc. I did it by becoming a para for a high school's special education program when I was 19. It forced me to talk and explain well, and to see how other autists get stuck in the same problems. Don't think you're stuck like this forever, eventually you will develop

Just being an autistic maniac works with a couple caveats. You need a few social skills. Mostly just showing interest in others, not rambling, and learning to not be outwardly judgmental of people so long as they are kind (genuinely kind, be as much of a dick as you want to really passive aggressive people). AND you also kinda sorta have your life together (if 25+).. Emphasis on it only needing to be "kinda sorta" though., I basically just mean you don't live with your parents, aren't obese, and you're above the paycheck to paycheck style of living.

The hard part is learning to feel zero embarrassment for being bombastically weird. It doesn't work if you half-ass it. Expect more people to hate you as well, but the benefits are worth it. If you work a job with a lot of social rules, start viewing your job as nothing more than an exchange of time for money and then completely be yourself outside of work. Environments with a lot of social rules are extremely cucked and, as an autist, there is no social success to be found in such environments unless you're okay with having a very submissive personality.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
"Eating disorders" comprise a wide variety of dysmorphic disorders and behaviours. This includes people on both extremes of the scales, fat and muscle based, and if we use the medical term body dysmorphia it also includes cosmetic surgeries.

It is important to understand that a behaviour is not a disorder.

The details of any of these disorders and behaviours are dependent on specifically what you are talking about.

If we're talking about something like diagnosed anorexia nervosa, yes the person can literally see an overweight person in the mirror and is ignorant of their actual look.

If we're talking about something like bulimia, it's an emotional coping mechanism.

There are extreme versions of people comparing their bodies to others and trying to mimic them. There's eating disorders that result in obesity (these are over represented and treated as normal by society these days).

What exactly are we talking about OP?

t. Doctor.

posts.com:
hello anons. I'm a 1st year undergrad living in London and it's about time I start looking for a new place to live (in private accommodation w Unite Students rn). i didn't make any friends in my first few months so if I have to find people it'll have to be on Facebook lol.

I don't have any specific questions, just lookin for any advice at all. It really helps bc my family live in social housing and don't know stuff ab London.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: bump :(( pls

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28185067
My girlfriend stays in a unite, it's pretty comfy and hassle free but attracts generally anti social people (lots of cliquey Asians). You messed up a bit by not going into more social accomodation. But trust me it's not too late to meet people, wtf do you mean meet anyone on Facebook. no. you are in university, the single best place to meet anyone even if you are a complete sperg. go through your unis page that lists all the societies and join and go to any events that you have even a slight interest in. some are better than others e.g an outdoor/hiking society that organises trips is great, any off beat or quirky societies are usually pretty good too to meet cool people. if you want to start slow join a more nerdy society and feel less social pressure to interact with lower social status people I guess.

Also sign up to some extra curricular stuff that the uni gives you opportunities for, it's a good way to meet people. Your subject should also have some group activity stuff which is great for meeting people too. ideally you would stay at unite until you find someone to move in with, but problem is you can't really definitively know that you will. I just think that if you moved in with random people, let's say professionals while you are a student you would feel the sense of alienation more. at least now you're surrounded by students in unite even if you don't interact with them. also lookout for unite doing events, at least my gf one sometimes does a movie night or something like that and the people that do attend those are probably in a similar situation to you and want to meet some people. hopefully some of this helped t. final year student

I ran away from my deteriorating mental health for the past 4 years through excessive gaming, porn, and junk food. I got a B.A. during that time, worked for a while, and am now starting an M.S. But I am rotting from the inside.

The only real friends I have are from in HS, and I can tell they are not going down a good path. Gaming until 3 AM most nights, drinking, working dead-end jobs. I did not make friends in college, which you can blame on the pandemic. I optimized my time to play video games and neglected every other aspect of my life.

It does not help that I developed a debilitating obsession with my ex-GF following HS and during all this time. Neither of us put much effort into the relationship; there was some intimacy, but it faded, and she left me for college. I let her walk all over me during the relationship; I was desperate and weak, and still am.

I developed a lingering resentment for her because we never had sex. As a result, I delved into increasingly degenerate porn and video games to numb my mind and soul.

I achieved just that, but the problems are still there. I am stunted socially and romantically. I've been feeling increasingly depressed and anxious. I have also had off/on bouts of erection/morning wood issues over the past couple years which has caused me tremendous anxiety (I am 22). My obsessive tendencies have only worsened, and I feel like I am becoming a hypochondriac.

I am quitting porn, exercising, and developing a healthier diet because I know things won't get better if I don't put in the work. I should see a doctor regarding my health concerns too. However, I think gaming addiction is at the heart of my issues. They have been a big part of my life since I was young, but there are many opportunities I missed out on in my adolescence because I decided to game. I didn't even get my driver's license until after HS, so I had to have my pseudo-GF pick me up to do things.

I am sick of living a numb existence. It is time to change.

I'm 28. I took out an unsecured loan at an exorbitantly high interest rate a little over a year go to start a business (self employment). It was for about $25,000, with the interest total repayment (according to the schedule) has me locked in for five years total (I'm through my first year).

I was doing just fine with what little starting capital I had, but I took out the loan because I figured I could put that capital to use sooner to increase the returns on the investment and just pay the loan back faster (no early repayment penalty for repaying the loan sooner).

I jumped the gun and quit my job and started doing my business work full time. Needless to say, I completely mismanaged the money and the business and the business failed six months after I had taken the loan out (I had been self-employed using start capital I had saved for about three months prior).

Fast forward a year later, I'm getting killed financially because of the monthly loan repayment. I don't make the same kind of money I made working at my last job (made about 100k annually if I had stayed). I now make half of that, working seven days a week.

I can't find a way out of this Hell. Everything I thought I wanted in my life growing up the past ten years is basically gone. Music was this big instrumental passion to my life and I haven't touched a fucking guitar to write a song in over a year. I hardly can play in time anymore without fucking it up. I can't bring myself to show my face in public because of all of my failures.

I don't want to live like this anymore but I see no way out. I've got to be up again for work in like five hours and I can't sleep. I just hate myself through and through. I hate everything about myself. Everything. I'm just one big failure of a human being and I want to die.

This is the real shit here.

The office environment is a warzone; don't you forget it. You have to be psychologically unwell in order to thrive in such an environment.
And there are really only two types of people who thrive in it: tyrants and bitches. If you don't at least partially fall into one of these categories then you're going to get chewed up. This is especially true when you're good at what you do because when you're good at what you do you become a threat to those above you. Most managers do 1/4 of the work of the floor staff yet they make at least double their salary. Don't think they're going to let you encroach upon their position without a fight.

Of course you can try to stand your ground but it will almost assuredly get worse if you do. Usually by way of the "it's all your fault" game: regardless of the extent of their role in the problem, they will somehow find a way to turn it all around on you so it's your fault and not theirs. And don't expect HR or anyone else to come to your rescue; that's not how it works. Even when managers are in the wrong HR will protect them right up until the bitter end. Now if you were a bitch you would be able to take this all quietly but for people like you you're going to eventually reach a breaking point where you either snap and tell these fuckers what's what or you're going to go home during your lunch break and blow your fucking brains out.

If you want to play the corporate game then keep moving jobs every two years, even if that means you have to relocate. There's about a two year honeymoon period at these places before the masks come off and it really becomes hell. Get out before then. And don't settle for a lesser job title when you do; keep acquiring higher and higher job titles until you're high enough up the ladder that you have some say in things.

If you don't have it in you to play the game this way then you're going to be in for a rough ride brother.

To deal with the lesser-bitch you mustn't do them any favors.
Their game is to get by on the backs of others, if you present your back to them they're going to take every advantage of it.

When you work with them make sure that you clearly delineate and separate your responsibilities from theirs. In this way your work will stand out while theirs will fall flat on its face. The lesser-bitch, knowing that they can't achieve your quality of work, will inevitably reach out to at some point during the project to ask you for a little of this and a little of that in an attempt to get you do their work for them. If you give in and give them what they want then you will only succeed in continuing to enable their dominance over you. Of course turning in a shoddy project comes with its own risks since it's the team's responsibility to ensure that the project is successful. But to weed out the lesser-bitch you'll have to put some skin on the line. They will continue going unnoticed unless you can remove their protective layer. When means you'll have to risk submitting subpar work in order to remove the lesser-bitch's protective layer.
What's most important here is that you have a written record of each team member's responsibilities so that there can be no question of who was responsible for what part of the project. This will help when it comes time for management to mete out punishment as most of it will fall on the bitch instead of you or the others.

The riskier way of approaching the lesser-bitch is to call them out directly for their bullshit. Remember, they're a bitch, they play passive-aggressively and expect the same in return. Assertively call them out on their game and it's possible to change their dynamic with you instantly. But remember, they're a bitch so they will probably run and appeal to a higher authority—their tyrant of choice, HR or whomever else they can muster—to slap you on the wrist and put you back in your place.

>>28187087
To take on such a topic would require a book-sized reply just to scratch the surface. And as I'm already over-simplifying the complicated set of relationship dynamics which exist within the corporate environment, it would be an act of absurdity to take it further. If I were to extend this method of description outside of the workplace I would surely be projecting to you a state of unreality which you could mistake for the real thing.

In these situations I prefer to pose questions instead. These questions are mostly rhetorical; they're meant to induce understanding, not answers.
In no particular order:

Are descriptions reality? Is the map the territory?
Are the people that you're describing just as you've described, or has something been left out?
Why do you suppose some people surround themselves with those who affirm/reaffirm their fantastical reality?
What do you think happens to such a person when their fictitious reality becomes deflated?
What happens when their false sense of self-importance erodes and they can no longer suck other into it?
Are you not in that position yourself? A position where your reality and autonomy are being eroded by another?
Is it that person's fault that they're that way?
Is it all their fault or just some?
As you point the finger at them, can they not too point the finger at someone who wronged them?
What about the person they're pointing their finger at?
What tends to happen when you force?
Is forced change genuine change?
How can an organism escape its environment?
How does an organism affirm its non-affiliation with its environment?
How do you suppose an organism escapes a fictitious environment?
Is their fictitious reality not itself a manifestation of the true reality, or is it just simply unreality?
Are you sure that what you're feeling to be true is really true?
What if it's false?
What do you feel when you ponder the following: This statement is false.

Well, I think we can stop there.

>>28188040
How about we start with leaders.

There's nothing the corporate environment hates more than a leader, especially a new leader whose presence fractures the existing homeostasis. Of course all you'll hear from corporate execs is their unending desire for all of their employees to become empowered leaders. But there's nothing corporate execs hate more than someone who can lead people; not by force, but simply by their nature.

Leadership is a quality that really can't be taught for to lead by a book isn't leadership at all. When a genuine leader enters the corporate environment an invisible fire gets lit. Suddenly the floor staff are presented with a person who's a human being, someone they can relate to. He doesn't lord over them, he doesn't make them live in fear and he treats them well. He removes time tracking tools, cameras and other methods of inducing fear and control within the workplace. Though the execs tell him to patrol the floor to ensure compliance he refuses for he knows doing so only induces an environment of mistrust. He knows intuitively that without trust there can be no degree of health and that to continue systems of mistrust is to shoot yourself in your own foot. But he doesn't stop there, he fights to ensure that the people who have been underappreciated are brought into the light and that they receive just compensation for their work.

As the trust grows so too does the people's love for him; soon the leader and his men become one. And there's no greater fear for corporate execs than a unified floor staff united together with a leader. He carries himself with a fire they can't even begin to fake and they can't stand it. What if he turns against us? What if he comes for our jobs? They've got the numbers.
So you know what they do? They send him off to an all expenses paid leadership training course.
In this way their point gets across immediately: know your place motherfucker or we're going to make your life a living hell.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28188594
I was describing my own story with that one.
I had no intention of taking power from anyone but intent doesn't matter when one perceives they're being aggressed upon. The story goes on past that but that part of my life is well in the past now.

I haven't really met anyone else like that. I don't think the corporate environment attracts leaders all that much really, it's not the place for them. Of course the image of the corporate board room is that of real serious, well-dressed businessmen who evoke the idea of leadership. But that's about where the leadership begins and ends. The executive level is more like a good ol' boys drinking club, at least from my experience. And if you don't fit in with that crowd, well, you're not going to last very long.

What I've been talking about are more of the extreme personalities which you may encounter. But these archetypes are more or less conversational vehicles; they help convey some of the relationship dynamics that occur. People don't fit in a box, they express themselves on a spectrum and you'll run into people all up and down that spectrum at your workplace.

I guess if you want advice I would say get a thorough understanding of your environment before you converge on a point of judgement. But don't just understand the varying personalities but also the systems, the tools, the workflows, the approval funnels and things of that nature. Take some time to observe people, how they interact with each other or how they don't. With a lay of the land you can better determine where the weaknesses are and where the landmines are that you need to avoid. A lay of the land will also allow you to make your own role for yourself as you can provide solutions to help fix weak areas. If your direct report manager is a fair person then they may even delegate the responsibility for it to you which could greatly help your career.

Also FYI, the 20/80 thing is:
>better rendered as the Pareto Principle
>applies to all normalized data with a definite lower bound and indefinite upper bound (if that makes sense)
>e.g. 20% of wolves kill 80% of the pack's prey
>e.g. 20% of the floor gets 80% of the steps
>e.g. 20% of the letters are used 80% of the time
>etc.
Vsauce has a video on it that's pretty good.

Not only that, but two big take-aways:
(1) It is a fractal, meaning a mathematical pattern that repeats upon itself.
What does this mean? Well, take a normal 80/20: 20% of the wolves kill 80% of the prey. Now, "Computer, enhance. Zoom in." Look at the top 20% of the 20% of wolves. You will find they kill 80% of the 80% of the prey.
Are you still with me?
(2) All of this applies to women too. We do ourselves a disservice even thinking of it in a gendered fashion. That is, they too have an 80/20 dynamic. For whatever reason, people seem less sensitive to it.

How much of these messaging and rating disparities are caused by, for lack of a better word, "cultural norms"? As a man who had success online, I used the strategy of swiping right on everything. If you are ugly enough, swiping right on everything takes time out of the process. Heavily considering girls just makes no sense when there's a <5% chance they match with you anyway (let alone date you), so why waste time doing it?
There are also other confounding variables. Are men just taking worse pictures and making lower quality profiles, especially in this older data based on Millennials (whereas we're more concerned with Gen Z)? Are women just spending less time on these apps because they are less horny, and therefore choose to only interact with the higher men selectively?
There's a lot of questions here and not good answers. I actually do think you could do an interesting dating app study. Imagine at a school like Stanford's psych department, they build their own Tinder-clone; they bribe ~2k undergrads into signing up, notifications on, with extra bonuses for daily streaks of using it; they harvest the data. It would cost a lot, no one would fund it, and it would probably explode because of sexual harassment and stuff, but it would be the definitive case study.
